annotations.assign task: The speaker is assigning the task of giving a brief introduction to each participant.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker is introducing their research interests, which is a novel concept in the context of the introductions.

speaker: CM
transcript: Yes. Uh, my name is Carlos Morales. I'm at the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at UCLA. I work in electrocatalysis. Uh, my interest is in decoupling mass transport effects from many of the chemistries that we're interested in nitrogen reduction, CO2 reduction, uh, and coming up with principles how to scale up these devices.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is defining their research interests within electrocatalysis, specifying focus areas like nitrogen and CO2 reduction, which serves to explain their specific research domain to the group.

speaker: CMc
transcript: Yeah. Hi, I'm Charles McCrory. I'm at the University of Michigan. And my research, we're also an electrocatalysis group. We focus a lot on electrocatalytic mechanisms, both molecular and solid-state catalysts for CO2, nitrate, etc. and micro reduction, etcetera. And we're really focused right now on controlling transport and chemical environment to drive selectivity.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is defining their research area by mentioning electrocatalytic mechanisms, molecular and solid-state catalysts, CO2, nitrate, and micro reduction, which helps clarify their expertise to the group.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker is building on the previous introductions by mentioning their focus on electrocatalytic mechanisms and controlling transport and chemical environment to drive selectivity, adding details about their specific research interests within electrocatalysis.

annotations.None: This utterance is simply a transition to the next person, and does not fit any of the codes.

speaker: JC
transcript: Sorry, I was muted. It's been a couple of minutes, so I think we're going to start the discussion. Just a couple of ideas/tips. My role here as a facilitator is mostly to listen and perhaps make sure that you all feel empowered to intervene and share your ideas. So please do. You don't have to wait for me to call on you, but I would like to hear from everybody. I'm interested in all that you have to say. As somebody who's been on your side and has been on Marta's position right now, which is to record, it's very helpful if you are able to build from each other's ideas and see if that converges. It doesn't have to converge, but think about it in that aspect as well. You know, how would you build your ideas on top of somebody else's? Because the goal of the recorder is to distill the big, more than just say everything that was said. It's important that the recorder finds the ideas that are gaining the most traction. That makes the report's job easier and also more impactful when you go to the report out, which will happen after we're done. So, with that, I'm just going to take a step to the side and see if somebody wants to get the discussion started by using some of the ideas that you wrote down.

annotations.encourage participation: JC encourages participation by stating that their role is to make sure everyone feels empowered to intervene and share ideas, and that they would like to hear from everybody.

annotations.expand on existing idea: JC builds on the idea of sharing ideas by suggesting that it's helpful to build from each other's ideas and see if they converge, which will help the recorder distill the big ideas.

speaker: CM
transcript: I'm happy to start. One of the things, especially going beyond CO2, one of the things obviously is nitrogen transformation, nitrogen to ammonia or just ammonia, sustainable ammonia synthesis in general. I think the real thing is doing that as low temperature ammonia synthesis. That could be direct electrochemical or probably more practical is to do a low temperature hydrogenation for distributed ammonia because the issue right now is when you do elevated temperatures, you have to do elevated pressures of H2 to overcome the thermodynamic barriers of increasing the temperature to go to the kinetic barriers of nitrogen nitrogen bond cleavage. So if you can do low temperature, if you can break that nitrogen nitrogen bond kinetically at lower temperatures, then you don't need as much hydrogen pumping in. You don't need the pressures of hydrogen which allows you to use electrolytic hydrogen from solar hydrogen. Or you could do direct electrochemical, although I think that's very, very hard to out compete hydrogen evolution for electrochemical ammonia.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of nitrogen transformation to ammonia and sustainable ammonia synthesis, which goes beyond the previously discussed CO2 conversion.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the idea of low-temperature ammonia synthesis, detailing how it could be achieved through direct electrochemical methods or low-temperature hydrogenation.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker provides reasoning for the importance of low-temperature ammonia synthesis, explaining how it overcomes thermodynamic barriers and reduces the need for high hydrogen pressures.
